comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: Bob Diry (aka Bob Deery) had a brief career as a middleweight boxer in the U.S., losing six of seven verified bouts in 1913 and 1914 (BoxRec page.)

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: whyaduck: thank you for the additional information about Bob Diry.  We will update the photo information and reload the description.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: On December 15, 1913, Diry, a middleweight, was knocked out by George Ashe in the third round of a contest at the National Sporting Club, in Brooklyn, New York. Diry was from Ireland, where his name was spelled "Deery." Although he had won a fight in November, this was his second loss in a row, and he would endure three more knockouts in 1914 before he hung up his gloves for good. Diry's boxing record: boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=73885&cat=boxer New York Times story, December 16, 1913 (NYT says he was a German, and had won several fights, but the record contradicts that statement): query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E...

comment.author: 8560391@N03
comment._content: Hi Wystan. I tend to believe the Diry was indeed German, not Irish, as another NYT link credits him as the German middleweight champion (see his boxrec.com bio). The only source I'm finding that says he's Irish is the info at the top of his boxrec.com record, but I believe that's an error, and I'm also going to guess that whoever compiled his "official" record there got most if not all of the results and info from the same NYT links we're seeing.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Diry
